awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-P: Human-Robot Collaboration in Disassembly for Future Remanufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective of this planning project is to advance fundamental knowledge related to human-robot collaboration in product disassembly. Currently, used product disassembly is a labor-intensive process typically conducted manually by human workers. Fostering collaboration between humans and robots in product disassembly will promote end-of-use product recovery, greater sustainability of American manufacturing, profitability of remanufacturing, and better quality of work life for future workers performing disassembly.  Technical advances will include development of a computational framework for action planning, human motion prediction, and the control of robotic partners within collaborative human-robot interactions for disassembly. The project team will also perform planning activities (a series of workshops, meetings and a symposium) to explore possible ways to overcome challenges of remanufacturing automation, and to build collaborations between experts in engineering, psychology, sociology, education, marketing, and labor economics as they build a multidisciplinary research team for a long-term FW-HTF research initiative. 

The proposed pilot research activities will establish an integrated framework that automates disassembly in remanufacturing via the collaboration between human and robots. The framework to be developed will seek to optimize operational cost, disassembly efficiency, and flexibility in handling the variety of dissimilar products coming to remanufacturing sites. The framework consists of three interdependent components: task sequence planning in a human-robot collaborative setting; human behavior prediction; and planning, learning, and control for robots. Additional planning activities, including a symposium, several workshops, meetings, and webinars will foster the integration of multi-disciplinary perspectives from academia and industry. Successful long-term outcomes of this work also include new product design guidelines, new business models of remanufacturing, and new models of their impact on American manufacturing and remanufacturing. The ultimate goal of this project is to develop the necessary research personnel, research infrastructure, and foundational work to expand the opportunities for studying future technology, future workers, and future work at the level of a FW-HTF full research proposal.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Office of Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI)

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Project Objective: Environmental regulations, consumer interest in green products, scarcity of resources, and potential profitability of salvaging operations have resulted in increased interest in end-of-use product recovery and have motivated manufacturers to consider remanufacturing as part of their business model. However, the cost-effectiveness of remanufacturing operations is hampered by many factors, including a widely varying feedstock of dissimilar products coming to remanufacturing sites, and the high cost of disassembly. Disassembly is considered as an integral part of many remanufacturing operations, including reuse, repair, maintenance, recycling, and refurbishment. While manufacturers have become very efficient in reducing manufacturing cycle times and making most out of the robotic technology to enhance their assembly processes, disassembly is still a very labor-intensive process. This proposal aims to advance a framework for the use of robotics technology in the disassembly field with the goal of creating a collaborative environment between humans and robots, while targeting optimized operational cost, disassembly efficiency, flexibility in handling the variety, and required accuracy.

Research Outcomes: This research team has proposed a human-robot collaborative disassembly framework with the following interdependent advancements: (1) disassembling sequence planning, (2) human motion monitoring and prediction, (3) robotic planning and control. The framework has been evaluated and validated on the disassembly of wooden toys as a pilot study. The team also organized a workshop and built a multidisciplinary team to explore research challenges and potential solutions in the disassembly operation for future remanufacturing.

Key research outcomes are summarized as follows. (1) A disassembly task allocation and sequence planning framework in the human-robot collaboration setting has been developed with consideration of several important factors including limited resources and human workers’ safety. (2) A sequence planner has been developed to assign tasks between robot and human in real-time while overcoming several challenges including the incorporation of real-time human behavior and disassembly rules, the consideration of the safety of human operation, and the reduction of computational cost. (3) A human-motion identification and prediction model with probabilistic interpretation and quantification of the uncertainty of human motion has been developed. (4) An experimental testbed that consists of two collaborative robots, a motion capture system, as well as multiple cameras and sensors has been established to validate the framework and related algorithms.

Other Outcomes: (1) An online workshop related to this project has been organized. It consists of plenary talks given by speakers from both academia and industries, an introduction to our NSF project, a panel discussion on future manufacturing, and a question and answer session. More than 100 people from both universities and industries attended the workshop. (2) This project provided students the opportunity to conduct multidisciplinary research, give technical presentations in academic conferences, prepare technical manuscripts, etc. Multiple Ph.D., one Master's, and two undergraduate students have received mentorships as part of the research activities related to this project. (3) The outcomes of this project have been integrated into three courses, including Advanced Control Systems, System Analysis for Sustainable Design and Lifecycle Decisions, and Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning for Environmental Engineers, as well as several conference presentations and university seminars given by the team members.


Last Modified: 12/28/2021
Modified by: Minghui Zheng
